For-Profit Radio Stations vs. Non-profit Radio Organizations My Thesis: The goal of any radio station, regardless of its profit structure, is to gain and maintain listeners. The station must provide what its audience wants, whether it is news, talk, classical music, or Top 40 programming. For-profit stations depend on advertising revenue to finance their operation, other than in-house promotions such as sponsored concerts or special live remote broadcasts. This requires a larger and more intensive sales effort and the staff to handle it. Non-profit stations rely on listener contributions, corporate sponsorship and funding from government agencies or private institutions. This type of station will have a staff specifically focused on fundraising, grant writing and community-based communication in order to maintain financial support to stay on the air. The question is; Is it likely to get any easier for radio stations to survive? #radiostrategy #radio #radiobrodcasting #radioprogramming #broadcasters #RadioNews #RadioConsultant #broadcastmedia #broadcasting #broadcastinglive #broadcaster

I watched this movie üëá on Wednesday night. I don't watch movies on Wednesday nights. I save them for occasional weekends but when I heard about this movie on Wednesday afternoon I made sure I watched it that night - and I'm so glad I did. As someone who has 'grown up' in corporate and business settings, exposure to the NFP sector over the past few years has been an eye opener. The people who work in NFPs and associated organisations are passionate and hardworking and committed and sustained by such a strong sense of meaning and purpose. They are incredible in so many ways and their work is so necessary. But as someone once put it to me (and I wish I could remember who) 'You are out there doing everything in your power to change the world with $5 spread between you.' That's an impossible and unsustainable task. As a workplace psychologist I worry about the level of burnout I see in the NFP sector. I worry that the passion, hard work, commitment, vision and progress is thwarted by unsustainable business models. I worry that good people are lost and great initiatives stall because the focus is always on survival. The conditions for survival are very different to the conditions required for thriving. This is not the fault of those leading NFPs. It's structural. And if we're going to make positive change in the world we have to start doing things differently. That's why I loved this movie. It provokes us to think differently about how we do things in the NFP and charitable sector. If any of this ‚òùÔ∏è resonates with you, watch the movie - and let's talk about it. Thank you to Dan Pallotta, Stephen Gyllenhaal and your teams for bringing this to the world and to Social Impact Hub for sharing it with Aus/NZ.
